Weston's safety and rights are paramount.
We will protect him from further harm and seek justice, guided by compassion and the principle that his well-being comes first.

All legal protections are in place and the offender is held accountable, allowing Weston to feel secure and supported by the justice system.

Victim advocacy & rights (working with victim advocates, ensuring notifications and input in proceedings).

Work closely with a victim advocate to stay informed of case progress and prepare for each stage (e.g., hearings, statements).

Call the prosecutor’s office or juvenile case officer for an update on the case status and ask about next steps.
Write down key points for Weston's victim impact statement (or questions we have for the prosecutor) as we think of them.
Weston Victim Impact Statement and Prosecutor Questions
Describe how Weston feels now vs. before the incident
List any social withdrawal or issues with peers
Describe impacts on schoolwork or attention
What is the current legal status of the case?
Is there a timeline for the case?
Is there a no-contact order in place or being pursued?
How will Weston be kept safe during and after proceedings?
What are the possible legal outcomes for the perpetrator?
Could this result in juvenile detention, diversion, or registration?
How do we submit Weston’s victim impact statement?
Can we submit additional statements or documentation (e.g., therapist letter)?
Will we be informed of plea deals or sentencing options?
Will Weston have access to victim services (e.g. therapy, advocacy)?
Will we be notified of appeals, release, or any status changes?
Will anything from the case be public or affect Weston’s privacy?

Over time, Weston grows emotionally resilient and confident.
He has worked through the trauma with professional help and family support.

Parents and siblings access therapy or support groups to process their emotions and learn how to best support Weston.

tasks.note:
Graham’s Hierarchy of Disagreement, a model designed to rank different forms of disagreement from the most constructive to the least. The hierarchy is broken into several levels, with the most respectful and intellectually valuable forms of argument at the top, and the least valuable or harmful forms of argument at the bottom.

Here’s a breakdown:

	1.	Synthesis (Highest Level): This involves integrating the valuable parts of an opposing argument into a new understanding. It represents the most respectful and constructive way of handling disagreement.
	2.	Refutation: This is where you correct the opposition’s argument and build upon it with your own reasoning.
	3.	Correction: This focuses on identifying the flaws in the opposing argument and explaining how to fix them.
	4.	Counterargument: Here, a person presents opposing arguments with reasons and evidence to explain why the other side is wrong.
	5.	Contradiction: A simple disagreement without providing reasoning or evidence to back it up. It dismisses the argument without support.
	6.	Tone Policing: This level focuses on criticizing the way an argument is delivered rather than engaging with the argument itself.
	7.	Ad Hominem: A personal attack on the speaker rather than the content of their argument.
	8.	Name-Calling (Lowest Level): The least valuable form of disagreement. It resorts to insults and avoids engaging with the argument entirely.

The hierarchy encourages moving away from personal attacks and baseless contradictions towards a more rational, evidence-based, and constructive discussion.

tasks.name: Dad was a chemistry and physics professor at Walsh University for 29 years, dedicating his life to science
education. A brilliant man with a gentle spirit, he taught me the importance of connecting knowledge across
disciplines and making complex concepts accessible.
Nodes.bio continues his legacy of education and discovery by helping researchers visualize and understand complex
biological relationships. I like to think he would have loved exploring it.
Visit us at https://nodes.bio to try it yourself. This one's for you, Dad. ❤️
"A tale of two generations of scientists
tasks.note:
My father, Dr. James Muirhead-Gould (pictured in his lab at Walsh University, 1986), taught chemistry and physics
for nearly three decades. Born in Berlin and raised in England, he brought a global perspective to science
education in Ohio.
Today, on his birthday, we launch nodes.bio - a visualization platform for biological networks that builds on his
passion for making complex scientific concepts visual and accessible.
As the descendant of Gerard Muirhead-Gould, the 13th Laird of Bredisholm, Dad understood the importance of
connections and lineage. Nodes.bio is all about connections too - between proteins, genes, and biological
pathways.
I hope this platform helps a new generation of scientists discover insights and connections they might otherwise
miss.
Explore it today at https://nodes.bio"
Third Post (Research Legacy)
"Celebrating the launch of nodes.bio today, March 5th - a date that holds special significance as my late father's
birthday.
Dad taught me that the most impactful research happens when we can visualize and understand connections between
different fields of knowledge. As a chemistry professor who loved physics and biology, he was always drawing
diagrams to help his students grasp complex concepts.
Nodes.bio was built with this same philosophy: visualization brings clarity. Whether you're exploring protein
interactions, disease pathways, or metabolic networks, seeing these relationships visually reveals patterns that
might otherwise remain hidden.
I wish Dad could see what we've built. His passion for education and discovery lives on in this platform.
Visit https://nodes.bio to see for yourself, and join us in continuing a legacy of scientific exploration.
#ScienceVisualization #BiologicalNetworks #Legacy"
Fourth Post (For the Academic Community)
"'Education is not the filling of a pail, but the lighting of a fire.' - W.B. Yeats
This was a favorite quote of my father, Dr. James Muirhead-Gould, whose birthday we celebrate today alongside the
launch of nodes.bio.
As a professor at Walsh University for 29 years, Dad lit countless fires of curiosity in his students. He believed
deeply in making science accessible and engaging.
Nodes.bio carries forward this mission by making complex biological networks visual and interactive. We hope it
will be a valuable tool for both research and education.
As we officially launch today, I'm reminded of Dad's gentle guidance and his belief that science is meant to be
shared and celebrated. We're excited to share this platform with researchers, educators, and students everywhere.
Explore nodes.bio today and help us continue lighting fires of scientific discovery.
#ScienceEducation #Research #BiologicalNetworks"
Fifth Post (Personal Reflection)

tasks.name: "A personal reflection on launch day
tasks.note:
90 years ago today, my father James was born in Berlin, beginning a journey that would take him from England to
Canada and finally to Ohio, where he spent decades teaching chemistry and physics.
Today we launch nodes.bio, and I can't help but feel Dad's influence in every aspect of this platform. His
meticulous attention to detail, his passion for visual learning, and his belief in making science accessible to
all - these values are woven into the fabric of what we've built.
As the son of the last officially recognized Laird of Bredisholm and the 25th chief of the Muirhead Clan, Dad
understood the power of heritage and connection. Nodes.bio is all about connections too - helping researchers
discover the intricate relationships within biological systems.
I'm grateful for the legacy he left behind, and honored to continue it in this new form.
Visit https://nodes.bio today, and join us in celebrating a launch day that means so much more than just a new
platform - it's a continuation of a lifelong dedication to science and education.
#Legacy #ScienceVisualization #InMemoriam"

#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -euo pipefail

echo "🔎  Generating Python SBOM…"
cyclonedx-py -o sbom-python.json

echo "🔎  Generating Node SBOM…"
cyclonedx-bom -o sbom-node.json

echo "🔗  Merging → CycloneDX"
cyclonedx merge sbom-python.json sbom-node.json \
               --output sbom-full.cdx.json

echo "⇢  Converting → SPDX"
cyclonedx convert --input sbom-full.cdx.json \
                  --output-format spdx-json \
                  --output sbom-full.spdx.json

echo "✅  Done.  Files are in ./sbom/"

tasks.name: Educate yourself
tasks.note: Begin by learning about various investment options, risk tolerance, and portfolio diversification. Read books, articles, and attend workshops or webinars to gain knowledge.

tasks.name: Define your investment goals
tasks.note: Set clear, realistic financial objectives based on your current financial situation, risk tolerance, and future aspirations.

tasks.name: Diversify your portfolio
tasks.note: Allocate your investments across various asset classes (stocks, bonds, real estate, etc.) to spread the risk. This way, even if some investments underperform, others may balance them out.

tasks.name: Monitor and rebalance
tasks.note: Periodically review your portfolio's performance and adjust the allocations as needed. This helps maintain your desired risk level and ensures that your portfolio stays aligned with your goals.

tasks.name: Develop a long-term perspective
tasks.note: Embrace the understanding that not all investments will perform well all the time. Accept that occasional setbacks are part of the journey, and focus on the bigger picture.

tasks.name: Celebrate successes
tasks.note: When you achieve outstanding investment returns, take time to appreciate your accomplishments and learn from the experience.

tasks.name: Embrace setbacks
tasks.note: When investments underperform, analyze what went wrong and how you can improve. Use these lessons to become a better investor and refine your strategy.

tasks.name: Seek professional advice
tasks.note: Consult with a financial advisor or planner to help you make informed decisions, review your portfolio, and provide guidance on optimizing your investment strategy.

Where in Scotland are curling stones made
tasks.note:
Curling stones are traditionally made in Scotland on Ailsa Craig, an island located off the coast of Ayrshire. The island is famous for its unique granite, which is highly prized for making curling stones due to its low water absorption and durability.

The granite used to make curling stones comes from two types found on Ailsa Craig:
	1.	Blue Hone – Used for the running surface of the stone due to its low water absorption.
	2.	Ailsa Craig Common Green – Used for the body of the stone.

The Kays of Scotland, a company based in Mauchline, Ayrshire, has exclusive rights to harvest granite from Ailsa Craig and has been making curling stones since 1851. They are one of the primary suppliers of curling stones used in international competitions, including the Winter Olympics.
